paragraphs.title: Targeting “BEST” Lifetime Value (LTV) Customers using Oracle Machine Learning
paragraphs.text:
%md
### Finding “BEST” Lifetime Value (LTV) Customers using Oracle Machine Learning

Heather has spent most of her time over the past couple of years extracting and preparing data for analysis. The large volumes of data need extracting and processing mean she spends most of her time waiting for jobs to finish and very little of her time analyzing the data. Demands from marketing are forcing a new approach whereby the data remains in the data warehouse and is processed there. The alternative cloud solution is more complex, and has no direct out of the box processes to analyze the data in place. She started taking a look at Oracle, and found the simple SQL commands in ADWC are familiar, and execute extremely fast, leveraging all the performance features of the platform. Further once she is done can can apply the learning models to incoming data on the fly, and allow end user analysts to immediately see mining results. This drastically reduces the cycle of data preparation, analysis, and publishing. It also means there is no change to analysis/reporting Data Visualization toolset that users are familiar with.

Scroll down this notebook and learn how to use OML to create predictive perspectives on data in ADWC, WITHOUT moving it. We will process a small 100k data set, but could use a 100M or billion row data set without worrying about processing time.

This is an extract of Alphaoffice customer information. We will first get acclimated to Apache Zepplin, the open source interface for interactive collaboration in a team environment.

### The Business Problem:
#### Increase Sales by Targeting our Best Customers; High Lifetime Value Customers!
Heather has a hunch that weakening sales may be due to the company selling to non-optimal customers; customers who perhaps have poor credit and fail to make their payments for their purchases. Heather has over 100 variables to consider so wants to first explore her data using simple charts and graphs, but then move onto using Oracle Machine Learning's powerful algorithms to automtically sift through her data to find patterns, new insights and to make predictions that target her best customers–those who have good credit.

Created By: Siddesh Ujjni, Dhvani Sheth, Charlie Berger on 04/03/2019

msg.data:
Finding “BEST” Lifetime Value (LTV) Customers using Oracle Machine Learning

Heather has spent most of her time over the past couple of years extracting and preparing data for analysis. The large volumes of data need extracting and processing mean she spends most of her time waiting for jobs to finish and very little of her time analyzing the data. Demands from marketing are forcing a new approach whereby the data remains in the data warehouse and is processed there. The alternative cloud solution is more complex, and has no direct out of the box processes to analyze the data in place. She started taking a look at Oracle, and found the simple SQL commands in ADWC are familiar, and execute extremely fast, leveraging all the performance features of the platform. Further once she is done can can apply the learning models to incoming data on the fly, and allow end user analysts to immediately see mining results. This drastically reduces the cycle of data preparation, analysis, and publishing. It also means there is no change to analysis/reporting Data Visualization toolset that users are familiar with.

Scroll down this notebook and learn how to use OML to create predictive perspectives on data in ADWC, WITHOUT moving it. We will process a small 100k data set, but could use a 100M or billion row data set without worrying about processing time.

This is an extract of Alphaoffice customer information. We will first get acclimated to Apache Zepplin, the open source interface for interactive collaboration in a team environment.

The Business Problem:

Increase Sales by Targeting our Best Customers; High Lifetime Value Customers!

Heather has a hunch that weakening sales may be due to the company selling to non-optimal customers; customers who perhaps have poor credit and fail to make their payments for their purchases. Heather has over 100 variables to consider so wants to first explore her data using simple charts and graphs, but then move onto using Oracle Machine Learning's powerful algorithms to automtically sift through her data to find patterns, new insights and to make predictions that target her best customers–those who have good credit.

Created By: Siddesh Ujjni, Dhvani Sheth, Charlie Berger on 04/03/2019

paragraphs.title: Get data
paragraphs.text:
%md
##### We have data of customers in table credit_scoring_100k with CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE as a numeric field. We would like to predict customer's lifetime value as High, Medium or Low and not as a numerical value. This gives us flexibilty to easily identify High Lifetime Value Customers and a company can focus on them. We will use this field to create a categorical field LIFETIME_VALUE_CATEGORY with values High/Medium/Low. 

##### <https://go.oracle.com/adwc>

msg.data:
We have data of customers in table credit_scoring_100k with CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE as a numeric field. We would like to predict customer's lifetime value as High, Medium or Low and not as a numerical value. This gives us flexibilty to easily identify High Lifetime Value Customers and a company can focus on them. We will use this field to create a categorical field LIFETIME_VALUE_CATEGORY with values High/Medium/Low.
https://go.oracle.com/adwc

paragraphs.title: View 100 rows of data
Total number of rows in our dataset
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT count(*) FROM credit_scoring_100k_v;

paragraphs.title: Check the distribution of CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE and label them as Low/Medium/High
paragraphs.text:
%sql
   SELECT COUNT(customer_id), range
   FROM(
        select customer_id,
          CASE
          when CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE >= 0 and CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE< 100000 then 'Low'
          when CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE >= 100000 and CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE<300000 then 'Medium'
          else 'High' END AS RANGE
        FROM credit_scoring_100k_v) t
    GROUP BY range;

paragraphs.title: Create table and add LIFETIME_VALUE_CATEGORY column

msg.data:
Table PREDICT_LTV_BIN dropped.


---------------------------

Table PREDICT_LTV_BIN created.


---------------------------

Table PREDICT_LTV_BIN altered.


---------------------------

paragraphs.title: Verify the count in the PREDICT_LTV_BIN table
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select count(*) from PREDICT_LTV_BIN;

paragraphs.title: Update PREDICT_LTV_BIN to categorize customers as Low, Medium, High lifetime values
paragraphs.text:
%script
UPDATE PREDICT_LTV_BIN
SET LIFETIME_VALUE_CATEGORY = 'High'
WHERE EXISTS (SELECT credit_scoring_100k_v.customer_id
        FROM credit_scoring_100k_v
        WHERE credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE >= 300000 and credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_ID = PREDICT_LTV_BIN.customer_id);

UPDATE PREDICT_LTV_BIN
SET LIFETIME_VALUE_CATEGORY = 'Medium'
WHERE EXISTS (SELECT credit_scoring_100k_v.customer_id
        FROM credit_scoring_100k_v
        WHERE credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE >= 100000 and credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE < 300000 and credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_ID = PREDICT_LTV_BIN.customer_id);

UPDATE PREDICT_LTV_BIN
SET LIFETIME_VALUE_CATEGORY = 'Low'
WHERE EXISTS (SELECT credit_scoring_100k_v.customer_id
        FROM credit_scoring_100k_v
        WHERE credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE >= 0 and credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE < 100000 and credit_scoring_100k_v.CUSTOMER_ID = PREDICT_LTV_BIN.customer_id);

paragraphs.title: Get the count of rows having NULL lifetime value
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select count(*) from PREDICT_LTV_BIN where LIFETIME_VALUE_CATEGORY IS NULL;

msg.data:
COUNT(*)
1124

paragraphs.title: Delete rows having null lifetime value

msg.data: Updated 1124 row(s).

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now that we have each customer's lifetime value category as High/Medium/Low that we have derived from CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE, we need to delete the column CUSTOMER_LIFETIME_VALUE as it's no longer needed for running our classification algorithms.

paragraphs.title: STEP 3: Run different classification algorithms
paragraphs.text:
%md
We will predict the customer's lifetime value as High, Medium, or Low using various classification algorithms.

msg.data: We will predict the customer's lifetime value as High, Medium, and Low using various classification algorithms.

paragraphs.title: STEP 4: Compare all the lift results
paragraphs.text:
%md
We used 5 different classification algorithms to classify our customers as High/Medium/Low. By comparing the lift results of all the algorithms, we can choose which is the best algorithm to choose.

msg.data: We used 5 different classification algorithms to classify our customers as High/Medium/Low. By comparing the lift results of all the algorithms, we can choose which is the best algorithm to choose.

paragraphs.title: Assign Prediction based on highest likelihood
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select customer_id, PREDICTION, PROBABILITY from ltv_bin_apply_data_v_rf where PROBABILITY IN  (select MAX(PROBABILITY)  from ltv_bin_apply_data_v_rf group by CUSTOMER_ID) and PREDICTION = ${PREDICTION='High', 'High'|'Medium'|'Low'};

paragraphs.title: Actual vs Predicted

msg.data:
ACTUAL_TARGET_VALUE	Predicted LOW	Predicted MEDIUM	Predicted HIGH
High		200	8384
Low	14212	138	
Medium	77	16049	39

paragraphs.title: Average Accuracy and Predictive Confidence
paragraphs.text:
%sql
   WITH
    a as
      (SELECT a.actual_target_value, sum(a.value) recall_total
         FROM ltv_bin_rf_confusion_matrix a
         group by a.actual_target_value)
      ,
    b as
      (SELECT count(distinct b.actual_target_value) num_recalls
         FROM ltv_bin_rf_confusion_matrix b)
      ,
    c as
      (SELECT c.actual_target_value, value
         FROM ltv_bin_rf_confusion_matrix c
         WHERE actual_target_value = predicted_target_value)
      ,
    d as
      (SELECT NVL(sum(c.value/a.recall_total), 0) tot_accuracy
         FROM a, c
         WHERE a.actual_target_value = c.actual_target_value(+))
    SELECT 
    ROUND(d.tot_accuracy/GREATEST(0.0001, b.num_recalls) * 100, 4) as avg_accuracy,
    ROUND(GREATEST(0, ((1 - (1 - d.tot_accuracy/GREATEST(0.0001, b.num_recalls)) / GREATEST(0.0001, ((b.num_recalls-1)/GREATEST(0.0001, b.num_recalls)))) * 100)), 4) as predictive_confidence
    FROM b, d;

msg.data:
AVG_ACCURACY	PREDICTIVE_CONFIDENCE
98.6636	97.9954

paragraphs.title: View data for High Valued Customers predicted
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select customer_id, probability from HIGH_LTV_PREDICTED_V;

paragraphs.title: Count the High Value Customers predicted
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select count(*) from HIGH_LTV_PREDICTED_V;

paragraphs.title: Get the cream of High Lifetime Value Customers
paragraphs.text:
%sql
   SELECT COUNT(customer_id), range
   FROM(
        select customer_id,
          CASE
          when probability >= 0 and probability < 0.2 then 'Very Low Probability'
          when probability > 0.2 and probability < 0.4 then 'Low Probability'
          when probability > 0.4 and probability < 0.6 then 'Medium Probability'
          when probability > 0.6 and probability < 0.8 then 'High Probability'
          else 'Very High Probability' END AS RANGE
        FROM HIGH_LTV_PREDICTED_V) t
    GROUP BY range;

paragraphs.title: Conclusion
paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Thus, we have seen how to predict high lifetime value customers so that businesses can focus on them and have a better chance of generating revenue. We have also seen how we can bin data, use various OML algorithms to predict as per our requirements, choose the algorithm that suits our needs. We can also further analyse the predicted data.

msg.data: Thus, we have seen how to predict high lifetime value customers so that businesses can focus on them and have a better chance of generating revenue. We have also seen how we can bin data, use various OML algorithms to predict as per our requirements, choose the algorithm that suits our needs. We can also further analyse the predicted data.
